content: The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" designates and provides assistance for high-intensity interstate gang activity areas under Title XV of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. The "Violent Crime Reduction Act of 2007" defines key terms such as Governor, high-intensity interstate gang activity area, and State. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. The Attorney General, in consultation with Governors, may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas and provide Federal assistance through criminal street gang enforcement teams for coordinated investigation and prosecution of criminal street gangs and offenders. The Attorney General may designate high-intensity interstate gang activity areas and provide Federal assistance through criminal street gang enforcement teams, including reassigning personnel, funding operations, and organizing meetings for effective operation. Each criminal street gang enforcement team established shall consist of agents and officers from various federal agencies for effective operation. The Attorney General considers criteria such as gang crime levels, violent crime related to gangs, and law enforcement resources when designating high-intensity interstate gang activity areas. The Attorney General may hire up to 94 additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang crime activities in high-intensity interstate gang areas. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose. Authorization of appropriations is provided for hiring additional Assistant U.S. Attorneys to address gang crime activities in high-intensity interstate gang areas. SEC. 3. Grants to state and local prosecutors to combat violent crime and protect witnesses and victims. Section 31702 of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to hire additional prosecutors, fund technology, equipment, and training for accurate identification of gang members and violent offenders, and to reduce backlogs and facilitate coordination among law enforcement and prosecutors. The Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994 is amended to increase resources for accurate identification and prosecution of young violent offenders. Authorization of appropriations of $20,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2008 to 2012 is granted to carry out the provisions of the Violent Crime Control and Law Enforcement Act of 1994. Additionally, grants are provided to state and local law enforcement to establish state-wide crime prevention databases. The Office of Justice Programs will award grants to State and local programs to establish a State-wide database for tracking criminals. Authorization of appropriations is provided for this purpose.
